etymologies: late 17th century; earliest use found in Obadiah Walker (1616–1699), college head and author. From classical Latin dēlīberant-, dēlīberāns, present participle of dēlīberāre deliber

definitions: A person who deliberates a particular subject with others, especially as part of an assembly or other body. Formerly also: †a person who engages in careful reflection (obsolete).
